table.name: media
table.title: First time being a robot driver
table.des: In the 2019 battle at the border FRC off-season event, I drove the robot I programmed for the first time in an actual match. Although I didn't drive well, I still understand how the event work by being a part of the drive team.
table.content:
Intro

In the 2019 battle at the border FRC off-season event, I drove the robot I programmed for the first time in an actual match. Although I didn't drive well, I still understand how the event work by being a part of the drive team. Here are some videos and pictures from the event.

Media

Conclusion

This is probably the last time I drive the robot in a FRC contest, so I'm very enjoy the experience. Here are some things I learned by being on the drive team,

  • driving the robot is much harder than I thought.

  • fully understanding the code from last year.

table.content:
Intro

I've been writing some blogs for my 2019 FRC season, so I decided to write a blog that includes all links to the other ones.

This blog includes all blogs on 2019 FRC season. Shout out to my team 5805. It's not bad for my first FRC season, thank you all for answering my questions.

Links

  • FRC OC Regional 2019
  • FRC LA North Regional 2019
  • FRC Houston Champ 2019
  • My first FRC season
  • Official code explanation

table.name: media
table.title: Multi-threading robot code works!!
table.des: This is one of the robotics projects I've been working on for 3 month. I did research on 254 library. And I successfully converted our robot code from last year to this multi-threading structure.
table.content:
Intro

This is one of the robotics projects I've been working on for 3 month. I did research on 254 library. And I successfully converted our robot code from last year to this multi-threading structure.

What is multi-threading

In computer architecture, multithreading is the ability of a central processing unit (CPU) (or a single core in a multi-core processor) to provide multiple threads of execution concurrently, supported by the operating system. This approach differs from multiprocessing. In a multithreaded application, the threads share the resources of a single or multiple cores, which include the computing units, the CPU caches, and the translation lookaside buffer (TLB). (from wikipedia)

Bascially, it activates the multiple cores in roboRIO so that we can have more efficient updating and writing outputs.

How did I start this?

When I went Houston Championship in April, 2019, I noticed team 254 had crazy good autonomous period. So I went to their section on the stand and talked with their lead programmer. It was a helpful conversation, and I started to learn their code on github. Multi-threading structure is just a part of their code. I still need to figure out the autonomous algorithm.

What I achieved so far

I've been pushing updates on this repo, which will be our code for next year. Here is what I finished and learned so far,

  • Working multi-threading system that can do the same thing as the command base structure from last year.
  • Action class ready to go(not test yet)
  • Motion Profile ready to go(not test yet)

Why this is crucial?

  • Our robot will be getting and writing data faster.
  • Now we have the potential to have the autonomous like 254.

My biggest goal this year

First fully autonomous robot in FRC history.

table.name: media
table.title: Rapping in a football game
table.content:
Intro

A video of me rapping in a time out of the football game(SM VS Mater Dei) on 2019.10.18. It was a senior game(last home game) so I was hyped and decided to do a freestyle. It was the night before my robotics tournament, which I drove the robot for the first time in competition.

Punch line

Although we might lose the game, we are still better than Mater Dei. --Robin Gan

Enjoy the video

Shout out to the girl who taped the video. And shout out to all the eagles. The NEST is the BEST.
If you don't want to be in this video, email me at xiangyu.gan@smhsstudents.org. I'm so sorry if that happens and I will edit the video as soon as I can.

Click here if the embed video doesn't show up.

table.name: media
table.title: My FIRST live rap performance
table.content:
Intro

This performance was on 2019.7.29. My performance(non-profit) during 2019 summer session at Stanford, it was my first rap live performance so I was very nervous on the stage. However, it was still an awesome experience. Shout out to Stanford Summer Session for hosting this event.

Raps I did

The rap was a remix of Call Me Robin(Prod by Young Forever) and To16.


Call Me Robin(Prod by Young Forever)

This is the rap that I composed for this event. I'm not a social person, so people hardly know me from conversation with me. However, the hook "Call me, Call me, Call me, Call me, Call me, ROBIN!!" made everyone who went to that show remember my name.

My voice and lyrics are not very clear in the video(maybe because I was nervous and didn't rap clearly). I will make a studio version later, and it will be available here with more details on this rap.

I combined some fast trap flows in the rap, thus, it was a tough show to rap it with limited backup. I could hardly breath on the stage since I was jumping around while rapping this flow. As a result, When I rap the second verse, I was a little ahead than my backup.

  • Lyrics by Robin Gan
  • beat by Young Foreover

to16

The reason why this rap is called to16 is that I wrote this rap on my 16th birthday. It's a slow old school rap, and it includes my stories when I just came to US and how I got to know Hiphop and started to rap. Like the previous rap, I will make a studio version later. And it will be available here with more details on this rap.

  • Lyrics by Robin Gan
  • beat: I found this beat long time ago. It said it was a free beat. But I still want to credit the artist. Email me if you recognize the beat and know who the artist is.

Shout out to Alondra Housing for giving me this paper award

Enjoy the video

Click here if the embed video doesn't show up.

table.name: media
table.title: Why do scouting apps matter?
table.content:
Intro

I'm talking about the significance of scouting apps and websites in teams of First Robotics Competition.

First, let me intro the official definition of scout,

1: to explore an area to obtain information (as about an enemy).
2. a: to make a search.
    b: to work as a talent scout.
-- Merriam Webster

In First Robotics Competition, scouting plays an important role in alliance selection, where top 8 teams(ranked by their ranking points earned in qualification matches) choose two alliance partners to join their alliance to compete in playoff matches. Here is an article that has more details on this.

What are scouts' tasks in a FRC event?
by event timeline

  • Day 1: all teams are setting up their pits for their robots. After this process is done, the scouts will start the pit scout. This kind of scouting includes
    • going to other team's pits and greeting the students there,
    • asking questions about their robot abilities(for 2019 game, an example can be what level can you robot climb?)
    • and their strategy for matches,
    • and team backup support(like how many batteries do you have?)
  • Day 2: this day usually contains most of the qualification matches which teams randomly partner up to form alliances. Teams can still do pit scout on this day. But the most important task for scouts on this day is taking data from the robots' performances while watching the qualification matches. And this is the part that scouting app will help a lot. I will explain this later in this blog. One scout usually looks at 1 robot per match. For 2019 game, scouts can keep tracking data like,
    • how many cargos did this robot scored?
    • how many hatches did this robot scored?
    • what level did this robot climb in the end game?
  • Day 3: this is the day that alliance selection happens. The teams that are in position to pick will use their data from scouts to make decision. This process is very important for an alliance's success.

Scouting technology

By asking question and observing how other teams scout from last year, I found out that most teams are using excel, Google Form and physical paper(scouting sheets).

Those methods for storing data work, but it takes foreover for the scout team to collect, analyze the data. I've seen teams flipping through a stack of scout sheets to put data in excel. Then, they use excel to rank and do other analyzations to the data.

A good scouting app or website will have a customized user interface so that the one thing the scouts need to do is to put data in the app, and the app will do all the analyzation works. Moreover, since the forms will be customized for competition, it will be much easier for scouts to enter data. Thus, those apps and websites are perfect for both pit & match scouting.

Scouting website we(frc5805) use

  • This year2019: Scope by me. It's the first online Scouting App For All FRC Teams, also the most convenient and functional scouting website in FRC. Here is a detailed project description.

  • Last year2018: Big Yoshi Scout by me. It's the mother of Scope. It has scouting forms that are specific for FRC competition 2019. It is easy to use and can analyze data, rank teams, make charts from data user scout. It saved lots of time from putting data in excel then sorting data. It worked very well in 2019 season in my team. Here is a detailed project description.

More resources on FRC scouting

  • Scouting Strategy by frc4607.
  • Scouting Builds Winning Alliances and Winning Strategies by frc358.

table.name: media
table.title: Found a membean bug
table.content:
Intro

Membean is the website that my school uses for students to learn vocabulary. It counts 15% as my English grade. This part includes sessions where students spend at least an hour per week answering questions and quiz which is generated by membean based on the vocab you've learned. Recently I found a potential bug in the website and wrote code that completed questions for me. The details are as follow.

How I started this

There was one night, I accidentally search membean hack on youtube. In the video, the person finds the pass button by removing the stylesheet of membean session page. So I was inspired by this , and planned to write a code to automatically answer questions correctly.

Algorithm

According to the video, the person simply clicks the pass button to get the next question. So I simply used .click( ) method to replace clicking it manually. Here is an example,

In membean session, there are two type of questions. One of them is multiple choice question. The website will take the user to the next question if the answer is correct.

If the answer is wrong, the website will take the user to a review question, where the user needs to choose the right definition the word that the user did wrong. And this type also occurs when there is a new word for the user to learn. Moreover, the user has as many chances to get the type of question right. After the user chooses the right choice. They need to click a NEXT button to view the next question.

SolutionI'm not showing entire code due to security issue

  • Checking question type

  • Answering Multiple Choice

  • Answering Review Question

  • Finsh when the alert shows up

Does it work?

Yes

It did do questions for me.

& No

  • it showed cheating on my teacher's account.
  • And I got 40 new words while testing this code, which will be more work when studying for vocab quiz.

Result

In the next day, I emailed membean about this bug. And they replied to me that they will do the same test and encourage me keep programming 😁

Shout out to this awesome company!

table.name: media
table.title: FRC Season 2019
table.content:
Intro

I joined SMbly Required in 2018, which was my Sophomore year in HS. I had a very fun building and competition season. Now this is a recap of what I did in my first FRC season. Here are some blogs for some specific tournaments,

  • 2019 OC Regional
  • 2019 LA North Regional
  • 2019 Houston Championship

Pre-seasonSep 2018 - Dec 2018

Before building season, I was basically learning the whole time when I was at the meeting. I joined team in August with this email

Then after school, I went to the classroom and met Andrew--the only programmer was on the team. I was very sure I will be doing programming. So he showed me the code from last year. I was surprised how different it was from the Java I known. I spent most of my time learning Java libraries like WPILIB & ETRE to be ready for building season.

2019 SeasonJan 2019 - Apr 2019

Highlight Of Our Design

  • The Double Chain System: it keeps our manipulator horizontal with the ground in different positions of our arm. This design save lots of time in programming. Shout out to Andrew and Aidan
  • Line Light Aligning: it was our first experience with lime light camera, which save lots of time to build our own vision system. Also, thanks to my team's rich enough to get one. I worked on the code and made a working vision tracking drivebase in the second week as shown in this video,
  • Held Button Control: during match, our operator is able to switch six different positions with four buttons on the joystick.
  • LED Driver Signal: By using Arduino, I was able to control LED's color based on the robot states to drivers signal during match. For example, the LED will turn red if the arm is moving so that the driver knows the state of robot. However, we didn't have enough space on our Voltage Regulator Module to wire this Arduino, so we ended up not using it, but I still keep the code and a video of this.
  • I explained more specifically on highlights of the code in this project.

Things We Can Improve

  • I'm not satisfied with the coding style.
  • Autonomous is not working.
  • The robot design can fit the lime light more. The arm this year sometimes blocks lime light view. Also, because the arm, the lime light camera can't be mounted in the center.

The Season Recap VideoVideos & Photos by Angela Zhang - Editing by Robin Ganlink

What I did on for off seasonMay 2019 - Aug 2019

  • working on the new cycled base code structure
  • scope -- a scouting app for all FRC teams
  • 5805docs -- frc5805 documentation page that includes most resources and links in FRC programming.

I'm so excited for the 2020 season. 5805 the new champion! Let's go!!!!

I sacrifice everything for Houston world champion. My goal is carrying the team to get a Houston Champion banner. I'm ready. Let's go 5805 the new champion! Flag -- Robin Gan

table.name: media
table.title: First Blog...
table.content:
Hello...

Hi. I'm Robin. This is my first blog. I'm very excited to present you this website. I coded it from scratch and used some design from codepen. I coded the first version of robingan.org(robingan.ga) in November of 2018. At that time, I only learned about programming for 4 months, so I was completely new to web programming. I looked up lots of videos on youtube and realized how easy it is to code a website. And I was very passionate about making my personal web page.

Time Line of robingan.org

  • 2018.11: start to work on this website(called robingan.ga at that time).
  • 2018.12: main layout was done.
  • 2019.5: add php and sorting function on project page
  • 2019.7: add grid layout and sql for storing story and project page data.
  • 2019.8: realize the old one look bad and start working on this new version.
  • 2019.9: robingan.org the new version is done.
  • 2019.10: most blogs and projects content were put in.

Enjoy your journey here...
